awd_titl_txt: III: Small: Collaborative Learning with Incomplete and Noisy Knowledge
awd_abstract_narration:
The accelerated growth of Big Data has created enormous amount of information at the macro level for knowledge discovery. But at the micro level, one can only expect a handful of observations in most individual users. This hinders the exploration of subtle patterns and heterogeneities among distinct users for improving the utility of Big Data analytics at a per-user basis. The objective of this project is to develop a set of algorithmic solutions to perform online learning in a collaborative fashion, where personalized learning solutions actively interact with users for feedback acquisition and collaborate with each other to learn from incomplete and noisy input.  This project amplifies the utility of statistical learning in many important fields, such as healthcare, business intelligence, crowdsourcing, and cyber physical systems, where automated decision models are built on diverse, noisy and heterogeneous supervision. The research activities will be incorporated into teaching materials for student training and education in the areas of information retrieval, machine learning and data mining. 

This project consists of three synergistic research thrusts. First, it develops a family of contextual bandit algorithms to perform collaborative online learning over networked users. Dependency among users is estimated and exploited to collaboratively update the individualized bandit parameters. Second, it develops principled solutions to optimize task-specific and general loss functions for online learning, which enables the collaborative learning solutions reach more important real-world applications, such as information retrieval and user behavior modeling. Third, it models and differentiates the reliability of the sources of feedback to optimize the overall online learning effectiveness, which is especially important in the applications such as health informatics, crowdsourcing and cyber physical systems. Expected outcomes of the project include: 1) open source implementations for the developed online learning solutions; and 2) evaluation corpora that will enable researchers to conduct follow-up research in related domains.

por.por_cntn:
The accelerated growth of Big Data has created enormous amounts of information at the macro level for knowledge discovery and decision optimization. But at the micro-level, one can only expect a handful of observations regarding the outcome of a specific decision under a particular context, e.g., personalized medical diagnosis. This hinders the exploration of subtle patterns and heterogeneities among distinct instances or individuals for improving the utility of Big Data analytics on a per-user basis. This project amplifies the utility of statistical learning in decision optimization, especially the bandit and reinforcement learning algorithms in many important fields, such as recommendation systems, crowdsourcing, and cyber-physical systems, where automated decision models are built from diverse, noisy, and heterogeneous supervision collected by their interactions with the environment. 


This project develops a set of algorithmic solutions to perform online learning in a collaborative environment, pursuing both theoretical guarantees and practical effectiveness. To handle distributed large-scale data, it also extends the scope to distributed and federated online learning, which leverages the information of local clients with privacy guarantees. This project also develops a series of neural network-based bandit algorithms, which directly generalize the linear and kernel bandits to explore the decision space with more powerful neural networks. The developed algorithms have been successfully applied to many important real-world applications, e.g., recommender systems, web search, and user behavior modeling. The tools developed in this project have been widely disseminated as open-source programs and used by other researchers in academia and industry. The scientific findings and engineering products from the project have been presented in research papers in top-tier conferences in machine learning, data mining, and information retrieval, including the best paper award in SIGIR2019, and in invited talks at a variety of seminars and workshops. Three graduate students funded by this project have found tenure-track assistant professor jobs in academia.
